div.p: The variety, a comedy, lately presented by his majesty's servants at the Blackfriars.
London, printed for Humphrey Moseley, and are to be sold at his shop at the prince's arms in st. Paul's churchyard. 1649.

list.item: Sir William, a suitor to the lady Beaufield.
Master Newman, a suitor to mistress Lucy.
Formal, gentleman-usher to the lady Beaufield.

div.head: Act i. scene i.
div.stage: Enter sir William (At one door:) Mr. Manly (At the other.)

sp.speaker: Sr. Wil.
sp.p: I ack manly, well met.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Noble sir William the humblest of your servants.

sp.speaker: Sr. Wil.
sp.p: Come, thou shalt along with me.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Whither?

sp.speaker: Sr. Wil.
sp.p: To see my mistress.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: May you thrive in your courtship to her: at this time I am engaged to other business.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Can any thing concern a gentleman equal with a handsome lady?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes, the receiving of money is more considerable with me at this time, than all the women in the world. But who is your mistress knight?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p:
I dare tell thee, madam Beaufield, the
lady of spirit, and entertainment, the only magnetic widow i'th town.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: They talk her a wit, and a most superstitious observer of persons, and their garbs; I never had the happiness to kiss her hand, or be known to her, but I converse with some who are very high and loud in her character; another timeEnter Jeere major, and minor.I'll wait upon you. Who are these?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: In what grott hast thou spent thy time, that thou art ignorant of these people? These two are held the wits; that is the remarkable jeerer of the town, and 'Has purchased to himself the title of a jeer major.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Why, is there a regiment of jeerers?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: You shall pardon me, there are sets of them, as there are of fiddlers; there is first a set of court jeerers, spruce half-witted men, confident, and fierce in their opinions; these are men that make themselves music, and their clothes make room for their wit; and go before in all companies: then there is the town jeerers, like hoboys or waits of the city, that think they are wise when they are loud, and make a noise when they come to plays, to distract the next man's understanding. There are jeerers at time of the year that go down into the country, and infect wakes, and fairs, and the sizes, with their impudence, with which they save charges, and are never without the name of a great lord, to whom they are cousin germane.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: But what has he deserved to be called a Jeere major, and to bear such a title? I have seen the rook.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: An excellent ill nature has preferred him to opinion: the other has merited but the name of a jeer minor; yet they can see me pleasant in their reproaches, and laugh in their own defence, which many times keeps off the cudgel.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Nay, jeering is a blessing that every man may have if he give his mind to it: but wit (If I remember what I was taught) happens not to one amongst five hundred on 'em. But I forget my affair.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Shall's meet and be merry this evening.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: There's no music in me without my singing birds about me, than I am a lord, and when I put on my habit of Leister, I am his own excellence.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Dost thou preserve that him or still?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I may chance by the false light of the evening march to thy lodging.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Dost know where 'tis? I am removed. (Whisper.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: So, no discoveries what prince I am.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: A match: that shape will beget us some mirth.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Your most humble servant. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: My mistress is somewhat melancholy, if he come in that fantastical habit, we shall have rare sport beyond his expectation, to have the ladies laugh at him. Exit.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: This is very fine wit i'faith, and soon learned I think; a little more on't sweet gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Jeer.
sp.p:
Suppose you were foxed last night; thus I come to you, and accost; save you sir; you must
know I must laugh all the while; how fare you sir? Do not some fumigations remain, some vapours not dissipated, a kind of vertigo, a weakening of the nerves, or so? Ha, ha, ha, what thinks your worship of milk now, thin broth, or a julip of pitiful six for a penance to settle you, or a hair of the same whelp? Ha, ha, ha, there's wit for you.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: There's no harm in the world in it, nor no exceptions if you laugh in the right place.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: Now imagine you met an honourable gentleman that had got a hurt in the groin; thus I invade you; but the laugh must hold me too.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: By any means, I cannot choose but laugh myself.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: There is no safe jeering without it.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: Sir, you have been at push of pike and received a hurt, upon some onslaught in some female service, ha, ha, ha; your breath is aromatic since you kissed your mistress, and your water outsmells the violet, ha, ha, ha; by the powerful — yclept turpentine, 'tis true; what pity 'tis you went without a charm, or had no acquaintance with a Laplander, to make you venus-shot-free? Ha, ha, ha; and how many French tennis-balls have you in your flank now? ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: You sat up at play all night, and lost your money; another now.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Not I a penny, I sent a buff gentleman that looked big upon me, after an ill hand, twenty pieces upon half a dozen oaths.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p:
A good pawn, keep his oaths, if he do not pay your money, take the forfeit, and if he be
a gamester he'll be undone for want of swearing.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: Suppose it lost?

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: methinks cavalier you look pale since you came from the charnel-house, did the bones affright you? you are a most religious gentleman when you are at dice, and do so pray for 3 fives 3 fours at in and in: with what devotion you look on the seven of spades and eight of diamonds at cribbage? ha, ha; how zealously you invoke the saints to fit you with cards at picket, or lebet.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I invoke the saints?

sp.speaker: 1 Jer.
sp.p: I speak to the Catholic gamester, that understands all games.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: By the way though, do you think there are any gamesters in heaven?

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: It is to be feared, they may lose so much upon earth, they will hardly purchase a place there, or if any get thither, (Which must be excellent throwing) he would be more called upon, and perhaps pulled down again, upon every dispute at play to be groom porter.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: How like you these?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: You shall both with me to my mistress, and help to jeer my rivals.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: Your mistress?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I mistress Lucy, lady Beaufield's daughter, my landlady mistress voluble has commended me to her, and I hope to carry her, if one gentl. that she loves better do not get her away?

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.p: We'll jeer him to death.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p:
That were an excellent way, I think there is no statute against that, I care not what becomes on him, he put bitter jests upon me tother
day before the ladies, and I making use of your wit gentlemen, he told me to my face, that I talked nothing but clinches; as I am a gentleman he did.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: O barbarous!

sp.speaker: 1 Jer.
sp.p: You shall wound him with his own weapon, and by a direction we can give you, you shall so jeer him, that he shall offer boot to change understandings with you.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: We'll make him so ridiculous, he shall laugh at himself.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: That will be rare; I have sent for my mother to town to be acquainted with ladies, and learn dressing; my landlady, hath promised to commend a gentlewoman to wait upon her, and teach her the art of painting, and all the postures of a great woman; I do mean she shall marry some knight or other, and be ladified.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: It will be necessary.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Though I say it, the woman is flexible, and has been in her days — my father might have been a knight, and he had not been an ass, and loved his money; but we lose time, let's to my mistress gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Both
sp.p: We attend sir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: The same day, a dolphin taken in a net at Woolidge, and ten live pilchards in a salmon's belly — strange things! the 13. of July, the catamountain kittened in the tower: an eelship spring a leak shooting the bridge, — here are prodigious things. Enter Newman.
Mr. Newman.

sp.speaker: New
sp.p: Mr. usher, how does your lady?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: She is in health.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: And mistress Lucy?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Both in the garden. Sir you have good intelligence, what news abroad? A touch to your servant.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Alas you are acquainted with the state mysteries.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Troth sir, I know little, or if I did, I would be loath to speak it, but to a friend, the times are dangerous.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: You're right Mr. formal, but be not nice, I know you are furnished with news, as well as some that give pensions, though 'twere to a captain in these warlike-times, to have it made for 'em; you being a quotidian ambler upon impertinent visits, must needs glean the secrets of the court and state.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Sir I dare trust you with any thing, but prey do not speak on't; there is a great man in the world —

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Think you so?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: That —

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What has he done?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: You shall excuse me; but —

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What his name?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: You shall excuse me for that too; a word to the wise; you can guess what I mean, and let that pass; and now we talk of state affairs, there is a packet come out of the North, and a box — in your ear sir.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What is said to be in that packet?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: There's the business, but that nobody knows.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Take't upon my word; you are a friend, I hear further at Mr. secretary's, but you must say nothing of it, you undo me if you do, the King goes to Hampton court next week, but how long he stays is uncertain. Sir, you see I put myself into your hands.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: But is this done like a wiseman to reveal these mysteries, to trust these secrets to one you have not known above 7 year, if I should inform what will become of you, and your estate? o you must be cautious, though for my part —

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: O sir! I know to whom I speak, and will tell you more, for I dare trust you with my soul; they say the Northern progress holds this year, and that the elk is dead in the new great park

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I hope not.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: 'Tis as I tell you, by the fall of a tree, do not you remember a tempest four nights ago? then 'twas, blustering times Mr. Newman.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: That makes Van trump so troubled with the wind colic, but now the Hollanders, as they report, have many engineers and mathematicians set a work, how to keep and vent it at their pleasure, and so to serve in navigation for their ships, that there may be ventus libre, as well as ventus clausus, answerable to the two seas.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Ha, ha! that's news indeed, alas mine is but domestic, but what do you hear of London bridge? it is whispered by some it will, and some again point blank say it will not be repaired; but make not me the author.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p:
And I do hear the camels decay at
Tibal's: but pray no more of it from me.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: You shall not doubt me sir, you do not hear of the dolphin —

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Of France?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Taken as Woolidge in a net.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Of Italian cutwork.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: The news is not common of the pilchards, the catamountain, nor the eelship?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Not a word.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: You shall hear more; I am your servant. Here is mistress Lucy sir, and mistress voluble.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: I confess he has no overcharge of wit, that will be your happiness, he has a good estate, and you may live with more delight than a court lady, he is a handsome man too, I am bound to give you my advice, for your mother's sake, whose servant I am by many obligations, she has been my customer for face-water, and pomatum these many years.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: But if you be so skilful, as you are professed, and read in the secrets of nature, you can tell by your art where I shall fix my affection, do not you know Mr. Newman.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: I never see the gentleman, but I am not ignorant that he matches in the van, and leads the file of your amorous servants, but —

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: But what?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: If you love yourself. —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: He is a well-bred gentleman, and one deserves my good opinion, he's here.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: They observe me —Exit form:
I kiss your hand fair mistress Lucy: what's she that looks so like one of the sibyls?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Is this the gentleman you declare so civil, and well-bred, lady? If I have any skill take heed on him, he has an unlucky countenance.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: This Gipsy will but cozen you.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: She is excellent cunning, and has foretold strange things, believe it.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: If my mistress have an opinion of her art, she may do me a displeasure; I have heard much talk of this woman, some say she is a witch too, and wears the devil in her thumb ring, I would not anger one of her familiars. Take no offence mistress at the rudeness of my language, this lady shall give a very fair pawn, the word of a gentlewoman, that I shall be of good behaviour, if you please not to interpret me too hastily.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: There is some text in your forehead sir that wants a comment, but I'll not so much study your satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Nay, thou shalt not be displeased with him.

div.stage: Enter lady Beaufield, and sir William.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Alas, I am not angry; here's my lady and sir William.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: You are master of an excellent language sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: You honour me too much, it is because you are the excellent subject madam, and being the perfection of your sex, an argument to create eloquence in every tongue.

sp.speaker: Beau
sp.p: Then I must think you flatter; these praises are misplaced. I shall suspect you love me not, or are not wise.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Why madam?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: You take such pains, and make a pilgrimage to that's within your reach; I must confess I like discourse, but think not all my soul placed in my ear; although I love a lute well, it follows not I should dote upon a cymbal.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: A cymbal?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: And dance as I were stung with a tarantula, when you are at it, roasting of a galliard? You overdo this instrument, give me your courtship in a phrase is fit to own and understand.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Your pardon madam; I affect not bold and overracked hyperboles, although I might insist upon the wealth and fullness of your merits, to which, all praise, that can flow from me, is justice, such command you have upon your humble servant, I rather wish my tongue a forfeit to perpetual silence, then with one harsh sound offend your ear; you'll give me leave I hope to say I love you.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: This is English sir, and some do call it sense; 'tis fair, and fit, when any lady's private with her servant; 'tis what I learned a child, I have not yet outgrown the knowledge.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Did you love so young?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p:
I understand the meaning of your language, 'tis not perplexed, and you may love me too, and tell me so, and I may understand you; what need compartments here, friezes, and words of architecture, that will make things hard to the understanding? As you could not build a sense in love without 'em? Yet I bar not the freedom of discourse, and use of metaphors: and you may praise us too in verse, or prose, to show the exaltation of your wit in company, but 'tis the worst
discourse when we are private.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: If I had confidence she would direct me — action I believe when opportunity invites —

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: To what good knight? be not mistaken, I commend courtship in words, that are made round like pills fit to be swallowed, and not ragged bullets.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: 'Tis a strange lady, I know not how to take her.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: My lady? Madam —

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Art thou come?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Is it your ladyship's pleasure I shall read today?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: By any means, the ladies will not fail, we should forget our academy: sir William we must entreat your patience, and master Newman. Vol. whispers to sir Wil.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Madam, the ladies.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Say I wait upon 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I'll take my opportunity.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: You will engage him to credulity, and prepare some mirth.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Monsieur galliard the dancer attends madam.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: He must give way to another exercise; sir William you shall do us a favour if you please to entertain a little time with him in the next chamber, our lecture will not be long, and sweet Mr. Newman the Frenchman will delight you with his discourses, he has a tongue as confident as his feet, if you can but humour him.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: You shall command us madam.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: That done we'll join societies and mirth. Come Mrs voluble.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: I hope you will excuse my imperfections. Exeunt.

div.head: Act ii. scene i.
div.stage: Table and six chairs set out. Enter lady Beaufield, Lucy, and other ladies, mistress voluble.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p:
It is an infinite favour, (Most excellent ladies) and must needs speak the sweetness of your nature and dispositions, that you're pleased to hear me, so weak and unworthy of the chair, rather deserving to be in the number of disciples, than a professor in any of the female sciences; but as your virtues are more exemplary, in this honour to me, the humblest of your servants, it will become me, in the gratitude to so noble a bounty, not to waste time, but succinctly to deliver, what I could not finish without trespass on your patience; at my last reading I did conclude with old ladies, that will cozen nature, and time, and abuse the men they love best; to these I only add, it is not Mercury to change their skins like snakes, but they must fill up wrinkles as well as hide grey hairs: your red leather is for country wenches, your white wash, or Spanish fucus is the best, but a tire woman,
or coverer of time or nakedness must be kept in pension: for it is now fashionable to buy one of her apprentice girls out of her time, as lords and gentlemen do barbers boys. Amongst other ornaments, ribbons challenge no mean place, the variety, and blazon of these, I have elsewhere examined. For your finest laces, the angel in cheap, but they must be dearer than others, because they come in coaches, for pride or stateliness in any thing adds charges. Touching gloves, might I advise, I would have a few selected ladies, to procure some ingenious gentleman at a reasonable pension to lie ledger for them at Rome for frangipani gloves, and such other correspondent things as may be of moment and great consequence to your ladyships: but then I must advertise, and most seriously, that he may be a man of parts, and somewhat smelling towards the Roman wash, that he may give you intelligence of that state, and humours of the Cardinals, or those that pretend to it, be they little or great, for this concerns the state ladies here: for your swarthy mountebank Italian, he utters sophisticated Holborn gloves for frangipani, Essex cheese for parmesan, rotten post for sweet powder, pickled white leather for mushrooms, and cozens more with his broken English, than the wits can get honestly with their best language.

sp.speaker: 1 lady
sp.p: The merchant of Italian sausages, a meet quack.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p:
But then I would advise your ladyships to have another gentleman sent into Spain for perfumes, pocket fans, orange flower water, orange flower butter beauty, aqua de Chedrey,
and many provocatives, as contra yerva, and joco lata.

sp.speaker: 2 lady
sp.p: It is a very learned gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: For holland, 'tis too dear in Spain, therefore for a conscionable cozenage over and above, here are honest Dutchmen will serve you most faithfully. For jewels, you may buy them at what rates you please, they add lustre to a lady, and you may sell them at a fifth or sift part, which is very well for a great madam, if you would put them off at the best rate, you must get some doctor of physic, or broking apocryphal captain, to show them (As if there were fornication in it) behind the door, hanging or curtain, which makes his fingers like jewellers cards to set rings on, for there are bawds for rings and jewels, as well as for other commodities.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: What do you think of this caution madam?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: For your linen, it must be fine, and fresh every day, therein consists humane delight. For linen breeches, though some think them cleanly, in my opinion they imitate a Dutch stove too much. For aprons, plain holland is most becoming, starched lawn was in Queen Elizabeth's time, and will not endure rumpling, every thing must be squared by use and elegance; but for your white shoes, rich roses, light-coloured silk stockings, and such variety below stairs, they are great inducers, as a learned man told me, (I will not say a divine) for love, most excellent ladies, doth sometimes ascend, as well as descend.

But still remember ladies, that your fan be so little, as not to lose the least smirk, or grace
of your countenance for it, for then being so small, when you put it to your face, some courtiers may take it for a black patch. Then for your oaths, I protest is out of fashion, I profess for a justice of peace's wise, I vow too masculine, i'faith for a chambermaid, introth for a launderer, as you hope to live, too like a prayer; never stir, would disadvantage a lady many ways, besides visits; for the active wenches of the time, may they be damned eternally, and lose all their designs if it be not so; upon my honour sounds well, which in a great lady can never be forfeited if she be in love, for great women have their privilege of nobility, and can never be forsworn like the common people.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Is perjury in women no breach of laws?

sp.speaker: 4 lady.
sp.p: You have the doctor's opinion.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: One touch, if you grow old, which I omitted formerly, when time, which is the moth of beauty, creeps upon you, you must be sure to have so many leaves and curtains before your windows, that you may show yourselves at more various lights than the most cozening mercer his faded and deceitful wares, for the youth of your white satin will be then but pearl colour at the best, it may be but ash-colour, and therefore refuse no advantage to give it gloss, according to the conclusion of a modern poet, which at this present shall be mine.

quote.l: Wise ladies must refuse no art
For age will snow upon their heart:

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p:
You have done us a great honour, and ladies you shall not deny me this favour to taste of a small banquet that waits upon you in the
next room, shall I show the way. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter sir William, Mr. Newman, monsieur galliard.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Me be content to have de little patience, and be my trot, me tell you, vat me have seen a today, de fine sport in de, me come into de great man today, me make de reverence alamode, come ill fault, and he make me de estrange a sir reverence de tird time, dat ever you saw.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: That was not civil.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: O monsieur, every man has not the activity of your feet.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: By my fat, 'tis very estrange a ding, dat they will suffer a des men to be near a de King, a de Queen, de prince, or de Princess, they vil marra de understanding very much.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Why monsieur that lies at the other end.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar you shall excuse a me, for de courtier alamode, dear de vit lie in de foot, begar there is nobody can be wiseman, dat does no make a de most excellent reverence, dat is most certain, dat is the best ting in de hole varle.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I am clear of his opinion.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: But do you think Caesar sir, or most of the emperors or worthies of the world, studied the liberal science of the foot, or puissant toe?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: No, but begar dat make dem die all unfortunate, for if they had tinke of noting but de reverence, they might ha' live a great a while.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Excellent well argued, and very clear in my understanding.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p:
I confess the wisdom of it sir, but
for the wit do you think that lies there?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Dat be de best vit can be possible, for your vit, vat is your vit? your vit is to break a de jest, vel, look you now a me, me vil break a de jest, dat is like dat a me lor, dat is like dat of de knight, dat is like dat of de gentleman, ha, ha, ha! dear is now one, two, tre very good jests, by my trot they are so very good jest, dat make a me sick wide laugh, and begar me vil make a de page, de lackey, and all de fool in de court, break a des very good jest, very quickly, dat is a noting.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: To any purpose?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What do you think of the grave aldermen? they are wise, and yet they do not trouble themselves much about legs.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Be my trot, me speak a to de King, and to de Queen, to give me a patten, dat none shall teach a de aldermen to make a de reverence but myself, and me vil undertake dat vid in one 12 a mont, but den they must do nothing else, they shall make a de reverence, vid de aldermen in de Paris, and dance a coranto, a cereban, a Montague, and dat vil be very brave.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: What faculties some men have?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: But what shall business do in the mean time monsieur?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Is not dis very great a business? may begar, me vil undertake to de King and to de Queen to make a my lord mayor de sheriff and de aldermen very fine a mask.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: And to write it monsieur?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
Awe, de write? dat is noting alamode, your speesh two, tre, yard long, pshaw? give a me de quick a spirit, de fancy, de brave scene,
de variety of de antimasque, de nimble a foot, no matre de sense, begar it vole be de brave in de christian varle.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: There is no question to be made.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: And be my trot if me have a Noder patten for de counsel learned in the law, for to teach dem de reverence, dat vil be very great varke, but my diligence, and skill in dat matre, have no despair, to effect in time dis great benefit, and dat vil make a de law flourish; and England a brave England, begar.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I won't doubt your abilities, but I fear the capacity of the gentlemen you undertake.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: But what will you look for now, for your pains monsieur? that is considerable.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar me look for very much, for 'tis much pain, and 'tis brave ting, beside me look for a statur of de brass, in de palace yard, ven me go out of dis varle.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: You will deserve it as a rare patriot; but what manner of reverence would you have the grave lawyers to imitate, you must consider their robes:

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Observe a me.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Such a reverence under your favour, would not become men of their gravity, one always looks for a coranto after it, and provokes a man to whistle, or sing when he sees it, and makes one think still, what you would have a month, a little too much of the activity.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar you no understand de matre, vere is your brain? dear is noting in de varle like a dat motion, for de gentleman, and for de gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p:
Yes by your leave sir there is something
else that is as good for them.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: I vil tell you now, begar, here is a de kinsman dat is a me, and he live here very much time, before he come, they vent in vid deir toes, and hold der cloak just a dear, and de hat so, fie, le diable! and now they valk vid deir toes out for brave genty, you call dat a de splay foot, but me vonder dat de lady no come, begar me no use to dis patience, and de vaite, pray tell you madam dat me have autre business vid de lor, and de autre lady have de use of my foot begar.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: O monsieur by no means.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Let us prevail.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: 'Tis no good you hold a me, begar, me no stay two minute to save a your soul, dat is de resolution of de cavalier de France. —Exit

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Would any man believe there should be so much folly in this cubit square?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Do you think he is a French dancer? let that answer you, and wonder he has no more capriccios. But these ladies are very tedious, we must have this lecture put down.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: They are more like to purchase Gresham college, and enlarge it for public professors, you may live to see another university built, and only women commence doctors.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: But now we talk of learned women, you have been acquainted with mistress voluble, has she the abilities the women talk of? they say she is a fortune-teller.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p:
She is for more than artificial white and red, some think her guilty of the black-art, she has foretold so many strange things; she has had two husbands, and prophesied long before, how,
and when they should give up the ghost, if she be not a witch she has the more wrong, for she is believed a devilish cunning woman.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Possible!

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: There's not a lady with child but consults her astrology, whether it shall be male or female; and the waiting women how long they shall keep their maidenheads, and who shall father the first born, the master or the servingman; she is held a sibyl in the city, and tells oraculously whether the husband or the wife shall die first, how, when, and where, and all this sometime by observation of the hand, or forehead; she can see a maid through a mask, and is excellent at stolen goods, for she can see a thief through a millstone as well as a conjuring glass; in brief, she is held prodigious at divination, and most specially seldom fails in her judgement of the two destinies, matrimony, and hanging, this I have heard sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Sir William your servant, master Newman? that's he.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: Jeer him soundly.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What gentlemen are these?

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: He has betrayed his ignorance already, he does not know us.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: What, not the major, and the minor?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Not the major, nor the minor.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: Cede majori sir, cede majori.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: Parce minori sir, parce minori.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Here will be a fine conclusion from these premises, and they were worth considering.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: These two are wits.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Are they your wits? Pray heaven you may not lose 'em.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: If you love wit observe a little, and if I do not make you laugh, never laugh while you live.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: You shall here how I will jeer Newman, my rival now; such wit, wit of the last edition: let me have fair play, and these most ingenious friends of mine shall be judges.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I think so, 'twill pass time till the ladies come.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Mr. Newman, you are a pretty scholar, pray what is wit?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: A thing you want.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: A very pretty problem.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Will you or these gentlemen be bound to understand me?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, that's a clinch, to understand me.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: A clinch?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I understand none.

sp.speaker: Simpl.
sp.p: O sir, a palpable clinch; ha, ha, ha, ask my friend.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Is that your opinion?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: There's another clinch i'faith, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Pray sir, what is't o'clock ?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: The mystery of this?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What is a clinch sir, do you know what 'tis?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p:
I neither know, nor care what 'tis, so I laugh, and swear 'tis a clinch, that's disgrace and reproach enough to any man. With what ease can we cry up our own wit and another's down, only by
saying that's a clinch. I think I ha' jeered him.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: O the ways to wit are much shortened in these latter times, 'tis a picant age.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: They have a gunpowder-plot to blow up sense; pray gentlemen take truce with your spleens, and the wisest of you three inform me what is wit; you have; no patience to hear me; or if you will not define it, speak something that is witty, and in fashion.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: I'll tell you then:

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: You speak English to be understood, oh base!

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What language is your wit?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: English, but elaborate, for example — now beat up your kettle drums.

sp.speaker: 1 Jer.
sp.p: Sir, if my optics fail not, I have read
Each mystic line within your brow, my genius
Is much exalted at your gaudy phisnomy;
Shall's to the house of mighty noise and surfeits,
There tinct our souls with blood of purple grape?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What's all this?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Ha, ha, I thought you were ignorant.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: Give him the paraphrase.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: All this is, he remembers perfectly he has seen you before.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: And desires you but to go to the tavern, and drink a pint of wine; here's language!

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What a deal of embroidery is spent upon I am glad to see you well; how long has this been a vulgar language? You would court a mistress rarely in this cabal.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: But how shall a man beget such high conceits?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Have you a desire to know sir William? shall I tell him?

sp.speaker: 1 jeer
sp.p: If he will make it a secret.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Why, turn yourself round as fast as you can, and the first things you speak, your head being dizzy, will be these.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What a bevy of buffoons have we here?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: We are at your mercy gentlemen; but you that had a patience to expect so long, cannot want virtue to forgive, since we had no intent to make so great a trespass; where's monsieur galliard?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Madam, he's gone, something displeased you had no more regard to a gentleman of his quality; his time was precious, and some other lords and ladies expected him.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: His absence will admit of easy pardon, 'tis a most superstitious fool; what gent. are these?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: They are things were meant by nature, madam, a cure for melancholy, we have had such sport and nonsense with 'em

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: We shall lose time upon 'em, please you, we'll take a turn i'th gallery.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Mistress Lucy be tender-hearted to these gentlemen.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: They are only fit for your compassion.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: They are worth your acquaintance, master Newman knows 'em; have not their wits a pretty edge?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Dismiss your beagles I shall beat you all three else, and monstrously, indeed I shall; be ruled, and keep your wits warm, I shall sling out like winter.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I thank you sir and you be in earnest; I
Protest major, and minor, the man's in wrath, away.
How now James.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: I am glad I ha' found you sir, your mother's come to town, she road behind me.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Not too loud, where is she? I would not have it known till she have other clothes, and better breeding.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: She's at your lodging sir.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Mistress voluble, my mother's come by directions, mum, and make haste; sweet mistress Lucy, I beseech you take it not unkindly if I depart.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: By no means noble sir.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: This is my man that has brought me news out of the country forsooth.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: None of your tenants dead I hope?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Some are coppyholders, and I hope you wish me no harm, but I vow 'tis not my fault that I must take my leave so abruptly.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: You have a cheerful licence sir.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: As I hope to make new leases, and sell a hundred acres of wood this term, I am very sorry, but I will wait upon you in the evening. Noble Mr. new.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Ha, ha, that's a clinch.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I am your humble servant.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Another clinch I protest. Ex. Sim:

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Now we have opportunity I prithee Mrs voluble for my sake tell him his fortune; I have been a suitor to know your destiny.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: It will be a favour, it was in my ambition to desire it.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: My lady desires your presence in the gallery.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I must observe her command, but you may satisfy the gentleman in my absence, and Mr.: Newman when you know how the stars have determined of you, make not me a more stranger.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I shall be only fortunate to be yours.
Now mistress voluble, if you be acquainted with my stars, and know what fortune they decree me, I stand full prepared; what lines are in my forehead, you observe so?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Pray let me see your hand.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Freely command it.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Some that do make a trade of fortune-telling (Which is beneath my practice) flatter meam for their base end of profit, I'll be plain.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Truth loves no other habit, you prepare me to give you the more faith.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: 'Tis very strange, but this is most prophetical, you are —

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: In love.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: 'Tis very likely.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: It may not prove so lucky, love is a melancholy business.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I think it be. Is this all you can tell by your art?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: You would know your destiny.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What please my stars and you?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Take this for oracle then, you will do something in a melancholy humour will endanger your neck.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: My neck? shall I be hanged? better the witch were burned.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Fare you well sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: A pox a your prognostic, she has put me
Into a sweat, and I do more than half

Believe she is a witch, or worse, in a melancholy humour; must I do something to endanger my neck? unth? I shall put myself into a desperate melancholy with thinking on't; I will be mercy, 'tis time to laugh and sing, thoughts do not vex me to a new tune, there's no way but to a tavern, I'll seek out company.

lg.l: Love by your leave a while, and lazy folly,
Sack is the antidote to melancholy.

div.head: Act. iii. Scaena. i.
div.stage: Enter Simpleton, mother (In riding clothes) Mrs. voluble, fames.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: I have obeyed you son, but I shall never fadge with these things you talk of.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Then you're an ass, every child can do it.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Ay, if I had been a gentlewoman of a child, much might ha' been done.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p:
Alas after a little time, you will take pride every day of yourself; I wonder this wench
comes not! what? your son has a care of you, and 'tis never too late to learn to be a lady; this maid I commend to you, is a very rare dresser to a pin, and will keep your linen with all variety of sweet bags and powders, that can be imagined; and for your rich gowns, she will preserve 'em with the new fashion-sereclothes, and make them outlast Egyptian bodies.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: But must my old mistress be a lady? that will be fine i'faith.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: The tailor has taken measure for a lady I am sure, and three or four yards of satin, more than will serve for a gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Then she must be kirsened, and called madam.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Peace and hearken to my landlady.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Besides she has the rarest receipts to destroy moths, and such a sovereign medicine against fleas, that your maids need never to squeak as if they were ravished, peeping into their smocks before they go to bed.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: That will be fine.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: The wench I tell you on, knows how to consume corns too, and for fidelity about your box of teeth, false hair, your glass eye. —

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: My mother has two eyes of her own, but that one squints.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p:
Then for all manner of caudles, aleberries, possets, and preserves in all kinds, and should you lie in this maid will be the most diligent creature about warming of clothes, and for broths and jellies most excellent, and for all strengthens of nature; then if any of your women be too apt to conceive any thing that is ill,
she hath her drinks of retention, and expulsion — but madam

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: She is no lady yet. !

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Sir I speak what I foresee, and therefore among ourselves, madam again, this maid is very discreet, you will know what that means, not troublesome when your ladyship would be private, nor suffer any else to trouble you, and beside she will never be in love, which is no small matter for a waiting woman; she is here already —Enter nice.Mrs. nice you are fortunate to be recommended, to attend this, (But a gentlewoman yet.).

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: She is too fine.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Hold your prating, and hear my landlady, have not you clothes to come home?

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: I shall think my stars have been careful of me, if I may have the happiness to show my duty to so noble a lady.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: She calls me lady too.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: They know what will become on you.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: O that I could speak so gainly; I am but new come out of the country, but if you please to be as good as your word, I will do the best I can, to be thankful, as they say.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: My mothers very raw, you must coddle her, you will have but a foul hand with her, do you think she will ever come to any good? the truth is, I am ashamed on her, and therefore be not a known that she is my mother, till you ha' disciplined her, she must live very privately.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: How shall her name, person and estate be published? do not you mean to have her a lady?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: By any means sir, and let me be one of her gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: I have it; do you observe the maid I commended to her? She is a gentlewoman always bred among ladies, and knows how to talk, and carry herself, before any knight or lord in the court: what, if for the more expedite way to your mother's instructions this wench should take upon her sometime to be her mistress, and in her name, before strangers, exercise some pride and courtship? 'tis a nearer way by example than precept to arrive at any thing; and by observing her fashion, garb, and language, your mother may be sooner ripe for a ladyship by at least two months, beside all the rules she may receive from us in private.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Admirable! My mother is a towardly old woman.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Old? you do not know how painting may transform age; and the wench is not so young as she seems; howsoever this will be only to strangers, and you may with more reputation own her for your mother among gallants, 'tis but saying she was married at twelve, and you popped into the world before thirteen.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I will leave her to your tuition, and this gentlewoman's education.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Then 'tis thus madam, come hither nice.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: James, thou shalt wait upon me to my mistress when thou hast better clothes.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: I have a new suit coming up from top to toe.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p:
I'll never live in the country again, such another clod was I when I came to London; mother
you must be dutiful, 'tis for your own good; but do you hear landlady, have you spoke the powerful word to my mistress? Shall I have her from Newman?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: I have read his destiny, and if things hit with his credulous nature, he will make himself uncapable of her affection; you are the next in preferment, never fear it, and leave your mother to our method and government, we will both edify, and ladify her.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: With all my heart: buoy lady mother.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: If please you we'll withdraw; you must be secret James. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Manly (In Leister's habit) the two jeerers meet him.

sp.speaker: 1 jeer:
sp.p: What have we here?

sp.speaker: 2 jeer
sp.p: The ghost of Leister?

sp.speaker: 1 jeer
sp.l: Thus I have seen him painted,
'Tis some humorous gentleman.

sp.speaker: 2 jeer
sp.p: A proper fellow?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: It is not dark enough; how they gape at me?

sp.speaker: 1 jeer
sp.p: Let's make sport with him, he shows admirably by twilight, he has not travelled far sure; such a shape would get money in Bartholmew fair.

sp.speaker: 2 jeer
sp.p: Are you a high german sir?

sp.speaker: 1 jeer
sp.p: Yes, 'tis a fencer; did you not hear of a swiss that came over to be beaten at eight several weapons?

sp.speaker: 2 jeer
sp.p:
By your favour sir, no, 'tis no high German, those breeches are not worn in Switzerland,
there is something of the codpiece —

sp.speaker: 1 jeer
sp.p: 'Tis not his majesty's operator for the teeth, that hangs about Fleet-bridge.

sp.speaker: 2 jeer
sp.p: He's not so handsome.

sp.speaker: 1 jeer
sp.p: Were not you one of the brothers that guarded the dial at bow church, and used to put Cheapside in mind of their quarters?

sp.speaker: 2 jeer
sp.p: No, he wants a pole-axe; do you think he came not off some conduit?

sp.speaker: 1 jeer
sp.p: I am sure he came not off o'th' saltseller, he is a size too tall.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: These rogues will draw a regiment of prentices about me presently, and then shall I be apprehended for some sea monster, and thrown into the Thames at the next stairs, to show their worships how well I can swim — have you any thing to say to me?

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: 'Tis English that he speaks, he is one of us.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I am one that will venture to beat you both in the same language, if you leave me not the sooner.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: 'Tis some that skulks in this disguise for debt; we'll say we are officers, and pretend to arrest him.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Nay then have at you bandogs —
sp.stage: Enter Newman, and gentlemen, (Their swords drawn.)
sp.p: A rescue?

sp.speaker: 2 jeer
sp.p: Hold.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Down with the bailiffs, arrest a gentleman in the Kings high way —Ex. Manly

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: So, so, he is escaped. Ex. gent.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p:
You cursed tadpoles, cannot a gentleman
walk i'th' streets, but such tenterhooks must catch him by the cloak?

sp.speaker: 1 jeer
sp.p: Noble master Newman, we are your servants; do not you know us? we are no officers.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Ha? If my optics err not, I have read
Each mystic line within your brows,
Ye shall both —

sp.speaker: 1 jeer
sp.p: Have our skins cut into measures.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: To the tavern with me.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: With all our hearts.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: We will be drunk together.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: You shall command us ..

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: At my new tavern where the wine shall flow as at a coronation; fifty fiddles, and a noise of trumpets come along with me; you two shall send your tickets out for wenches.

sp.speaker: 1 jeer
sp.p: Of all complexions, and degrees, from the madam Alamode, to the humble waistcoater. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: I beseech you Mrs Lucy make not me the author, I affect Mr. Newman, but this I received from good intelligence.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I am miserable; I did not think his nature could degenerate into so wild a change, it is some witchcraft, I must grieve for him though I dare not show it.

sp.speaker: Fo.
sp.p: There is a report, I would be loath you should name me in't, but they confidently say; I dare not justify upon my knowledge, that he has killed —

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Good heaven defend; then I am more undone.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Nay, these are the fruits of wine and surfeits; I did not see him bleed, but I heard it from a man of quality, and one that had been collector in the parish, who told me for certain that Mr. Newman did kill him.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Whom? my afflicted heart.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: It was an officer that was slain.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: The more unpardonable. — where?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: In the parish of All-hallows barking, the bell man never dawned since, coming drunk out of a tavern at twelve — he made no more ado — there was not such another dog within the walls; it waited upon the foresaid bellman a nights in his majesty's service, to waken the parish, and all day was hired out by a blindman, that begged, with a bell about his neck.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Is that all the murder he has committed?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: All? you do not consider the blind beggar that's undone by't, or who shall carry the lantern at midnight, to light gentlemen to the best ale, and a bawdy-house; but for my part I'll be no evidence, if the city will suffer such an injustice within their walls I can be silent, and think.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Would this were all the danger, but I fear since he took up this rudeness and strange carriage he may deserve more sorrow.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: I love not to meddle in other men's affairs, but I know something.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I prithee tell me all.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p:
The tavern he frequents he has made his theater at his own charge to act intemperance; o'er the great room be uses to be drunk in, they say, he has built a heaven, a player's heaven,
and thence a throne's let down, in which, well heated, successively they are drawn up to the clouds to drink their mistress health, while the mad mortals adore their god of grape, and gaping look like earth that's chapped with heat, although before within three minutes they were drenched.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Dost know that place?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: You shall excuse me, I know nothing.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Prithee be not so cautious, I am his friend, and pity him; if for my sake thou wilt but find him out, and tell him I desire to change but a few words, trust me, I may amply requite this service.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: You must then keep secret what I undertake, I'll do't. Be cautious to whom you speak, we must be circumspect. I will go off invisible. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Monsieur galliard, my lady expects you.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar me no like a dat reverence, me vil change a dat:

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: 'Tis the French fashion as you taught me monsieur.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Ouy, 'tis de French fashion, but de French fashion is always to change, and dis reverence displease a me very much, because you go back, back vid your buttock, as if some vod take you by dat, to vat me vil give a no name.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Monsieur Galliard my lady will be here presently.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Sweet Mrs Lucy.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
Dat de reverence is no good of de man, me must change dat too; by me trot me doubt dat dis great business vil almost break a my brain,
dis great varke, and before a mask of de King and de Queen, me can eat a no meat, no drink, no sleep, and me grow so very a lean, vid de contemplation, a so much, by my trot de privy counsel is no so much troubled as me be vid dis, o, le diable! deirs is noting, they sit all the vile day do deir business, me bissey boot head, and de foot cap a pie, in de French tune, and dat is great matre begar.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: You esteem it highly monsieur.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Me tell you, and me tell you no tale, 'tis great matre to make a de lor, to make a de lady, to make a de gentleman, to make a de gentilvoman, and de autre man to dance, and to make a de good reverence, for begar dat vil make a de King, de great kin in de varle.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: How can that be sir?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Me tell you, ven they are so bissey, to learn a de dance, they vil never tinke of de rebellion, and den de reverence is obedience to monarchy, and begar obedience is ale de ting in de varke.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I'll swear your state affairs lie in your foot, and you are wiser there, than some heads are, and may be a precedent for after ages; but what music would you govern the people by?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar by de best French fiddles can be got?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: What think you of an Irish harp, a state organ, or a passionate voice to a lover's lute?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
Des dull tings make a de men melancholic, and den they tinke on de devil, and de
treason, and do any ting dat is no good, but begar des French fiddles do fiddle all this tings out of deir head, vid such a jerk, as ma foy make a dem so fantastical, and make a dem as good subject, as any is in de France begar.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I must wait upon my mother.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: She will be here immediately. —
She is not right yet.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Here be one of my colliers, monsieur Simpleton, say you no dat de French fiddle make a de brave government in de varle?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I say any thing becomes a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Observe you dat? he have been but two are mont and he say any thing, dat is very brave? he have de grand understanding in de foot; tell a me, ven you hear a de little fiddle, vat is your tinke? is your head no free from de treason, and plot of de rebel, as your leg? begar you no stand upon de ground for joy of de coranto, de Cerebran, de marquis, de Montague, ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: My lady.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Me be your humble servant madam, and stay one two tre hour.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I am now ready for you monsieur, come Lucy the practice of the last he taught us.

div.stage: Lady and Lucy dance, monsieur singing, and correcting them in tune.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: The gentleman you expect sir William is come.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Madam prepare yourself for mirth, 'twill be a sight beyond the pageants.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: We'll not be seen at first, Lucy withdraw. —Exit lady and Lucy.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: What means this flourish? have you a play in hand?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.l: To bid your excellence welcome to this lodging.
Fore Jove he looks prodigiously, vouchsafe
Us th' honour of your hand.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Vat antic be dis?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: One of the supporters of the brewer's arms.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, does he take upon him to be a prince too, and will he speak?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: These ladies have ambition to kiss your hand, and have a great desire to know, how fares the camp at Tilbury, and please your excellency.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: 'Tis one of Arthur's knights of the round table.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: With his circular sippets; would you think that a pigmy poisoned should swell thus?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I am betrayed, there's no retreat with honour, I must be confident.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Laugh and jeer him handsomely.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: O that the major, and the minor had been here now, they would tease him i'faith, monsieur, ask that maypole and he can dance.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Plait il monsieur? A la galliard, de goran, la Princess, le Buckingham, heigh!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
Put up your rosin, and your catsguts
presently and be gone, or I shall find a grave for you in the pocket of my sleeve, and this shall be your winding sheet.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Me no play dat lesson, pocket de sleeve, dat is no tune de France, pocket, le grand pock: —(Manly offers to strike him)pardonne moy monsieur: me put up my fiddle and be gone, adieu madam, serviteur gentilhomes; pocket de sleeve? Exit.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: But I must not seem angry, lady, my business is to you.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Business to me?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I am bold to present a suit to you, I confess it was not made by a French tailor, I can make a leg and kiss my hand too after the fashion of my clothes, this served in those honest days, when knights were gentlemen, and proper men took the walls of dwarves; here's a belly piece, that looks like armour, with what comeliness may a man unbutton his doublet, when he seems to take the wall to make urine? your sleeve so near your nose, with a handkerchief, which I take out thus with a grace, after emunction, I put up again, with the corianders hanging out, geometrical breeches in several slises, in which a man is not ashamed of his thighs, nor hides his bow legs, which at the bottom surrounded with points make him look like a rough-footed pigeon, these things were worn when men of honour flourished, that tamed the wealth of Spain, set up the states, helped the French King, and brought rebellion to reason gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: So they do now.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Peace pepper corn; and all this at less charge than a mask comes to now, with the rare and new invention of hobby-horses; which of our two habits (Be you lady, but the indifferent judge, and squint not,) is the more grave and manly, his lean upper chin, or this goodly promontory? my trunks with a round walk paved with gold and silver, or your trousers, cut close to your dock, and drawn on with a screw? in which if you venture but half a crown, looks like a poultice, or a swelling in the groin; your habit is fantastical as the time, you squirt into your doublet, which you wear so careless as you had not buttoned it since you came from a bawdy house, where men of this garb, coming from the stews, march with that gravity as they came from a conventicle, so soberly they would carry it.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I see whoring was equal in all times, only the carrying of it.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Why that's all?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: But surely I do wonder, how my grandfather could kiss my grandmother, or embrace in that strange apparel.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: They made a shift knight, or else your wise worship had not been here; but that I want so much beard, I could show how your grandfather stroked his three or four handful of hair, to the terror no doubt of the standers by, and could stab I warrant you, with his two handed beard then, as well as you with your dagger beard now. It was never a good time since these clothes went out of fashion; o, those honourable days and persons!

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: As how?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I pray enlarge yourself.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: To have seen but a st. George's feast then.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Why, what difference sir?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: When they were installed, to see the twenty mile to Windsor strowed with blue-coats, feathers and cognisances, as they do country towns with boughs, and flowers for princes' entries, and not to go privately in a coach, with a page and a barber to cut off charges.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: How do you like this gentleman, is't not a pretty humour?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Then you should have the best knight of the country, with the ragged staff on their sleeves.

lg.l: The bear, the boar, and Talbot with his tuskish white,
O so sore that he would bite,
The Talbot with his tuskish white
Soudledum soudledum;
The Talbot with his tuskish white soudledum, bell.
The Talbott with his tuskish white
O so sore that he would bite
Orebecke soudledum, sing orum bell.

sp.p: Every knight had his hundreds, and these would take up all the taverns in the town, be drunk to the honour of their lords, and rather than not pay their reckoning, pawn their chains, though they pawned something for them the night before, and such merry catches then, as

lg.l: The hart loves the high wood,
The hare loves the hill,
The knight loved his bright sword,
And the lady loved her will.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: So the ladies do still.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: It may be so, but for your knights bright sword 'tis at pawn, or at home in his armoury; then we had, God bless the Duke of Norfolk, there was a jest, and another song.

lg.l: The great Choe bent,
The little Choe bent,
Sir Piercy leigh under the line;
God bless the good Earl of Shrewsbury
For he's a good friend of mine.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: He's very confident.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Alas, he is compelled to't.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: How do you like this Mrs Lucy, is he not a pretty ill-favoured gentleman in this habit?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: He sings rarely.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: No question he can dance too, in that disguise he looks like famous Cardell the dancing. Master in Queen Elizabeth's time, I have seen his picture.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: And he with your worship's favour, was held a wise man, and for his gravity he might have been treasurer, he went with that settled and solid pian-piano.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p:
And when he danced a measure, you should have had him with his rapier, short cloak,
his black cap, and his white feather, his single and double, both backward and forward, with that excellency —

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: And now he must be in cuerpo, or like a fellow on the ropes, or a tumbler when he shoots his body through a hoop; there was music then, and a heaven and earth, beyond your braules, or your Montague, with a la, la, la, like a Bachanalian dancing the Spanish morris, with knackers at his fingers.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: It must needs be a rare sight.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: He played to himself on a grave lute, or a modest cittern, with a politic quill, far beyond your Geofrey fiddle, or your French kit, that looks like a broken faggot stick, at the biggest, and sounds as if it had got the French disease, when it snivels out a coranto, or so hoarse with a cold, as if some great base fiddle had silenced it.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: What misery is it, the monsieur is gone now? here had been a French duel.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: But had you seen my lord lofty dance the galliard, with such capers, such half capers, such turns o'th toe, and above ground, you would have sworn 'em sound for nine generations, and for lavaltoes, la, la, la, etc. and then the lady.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: How did he use her?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: With wonderful skill, he put his right arm about her, and took her lest hand in his, and then he did so touse her with his right thigh and leg, and list her up so high, and so fast, and so round —

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: As what I pray, be courteous.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
Marry as soon as he had ended his dance she would lie down as dead as a swinged chicken,
with the head under the wing, so dizzy was she, and so out of breath; and all these wonders were extant knight when this old cap was new.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Is not this very fine sport madam?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Sir, you're welcome; pray excuse me, if being prepared for some folly, your garb and person seemed at first ridiculous; you have changed my opinion, and there wants but such a noble leader to reduce, and make this habit fashionable; it shows a proper man, and if I were worthy to advise, or could lay an obligation upon you, I should take it for an honour if you would often visit me in these ornaments, I like 'em infinitely, and the wearer shall be ever welcome; please you we'll walk and talk a turn in the gallery.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: You too much grace me madam.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.l: How's this?
I have wound myself into a pretty business,
She neglects me.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: In my judgement 'tis an indifferent pretty fellow, but that his clothes are out of fashion.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: They are most becoming; I do not like your new fantastical shapes, that transform a man from his masculine aspect; you appear to me like a jackanapes; there's a waste, and a long lane cut close to your haunches. Exit.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p:
Hum! she takes after the old one, I will try and shift myself, if the mother be taken with the habit in Qu. Elizabeth's days, why may not the daughter affect that in K. James', and so the humour run in a blood? I am resolved; she loves singing too, I am furnish 'With ballads, o'my conscience
this will do't; I'll fit her with a fashion, and about it presently. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: They are here again, and laugh at me: how familiar the turtles are?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: We'll taste some air i'th' garden, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: So, so, if I did love this widow for herself, what a case were I in? but I must not sit down thus, and something must be thought on for my honour. Exeunt.

div.head: Act. iv. Scene i.
div.stage: Enter mistress voluble, and nice, (Having a jewel.)

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: So, so, thou dost carry it excellently, it spreads like a proclamation, what a rich widow lies at my house, her wealth, and wit, must be exercised.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: She must not appear to be herself yet but in private, and the chiause her son has bestowed this jewel upon me for expedition, for he dares not yet acknowledge her; she wonders at herself now she is painted, and swears in her conscience she looks by her glass like one of four and twenty, and simpers, and licks her leathern lips as she had eaten marmalade.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Sir William has heard of her, and (Upon some affront, as I conjecture received from my lady) has writ to me, and articled already to dispose her affections, I expect him every minute.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: He will discover us.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: He shall never see thee act her part.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Do you think he can affect her?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Courtier's do not marry into the city for love, and this farmer's wife has wealth enough toEnter Simpleton, and James, (With his clothes.)buy a ladyship; here's the gull, away and be diligent. Exit nice.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: They'll fit you as well as myself for whom they were made in the country.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: How now sir, preparing for a race?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Is nobody else with you? Do not inquire what stratagem is in hand, there be more ways to catch a mistress's heart; how does my mother?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: She is pretty apt for one of her years: I can tell you news, there is a knight about her already.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: She shall have him.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Not with your favour if a greater person interpose, I have so much care of her honour, now she is my charge.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Mistress voluble, here's a footman, laced all over, inquires for you, he serves a French lord, he says he must needs speak with you, he has a letter. Exit.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: What if this lord come hither for the same purpose?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p:
'Tis too much happiness; I'll not be
seen thus, nor let my mother appear in her roughcast, use the footman kindly, if his message concern us, away —Exit Vol.
And will this fashion become me, dost think? I prithee tell me some old storeys in tother reign, thou canst talk and make me ready too.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Ah sir, I knew a time, when two and twenty years was but a merry Christmas, nothing but ambassadors, masques, plays, entertainments, hawking, hunting, winter and summer, Newmarket and Roiston mourn now, ha! had you seen the court foxed upon Goury's night, and the gunpowder treason began then; o we had rare sport, and then everybody was knighted, they hardly lest a gentleman in those days; and afterwards they got a trick of making lords.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: I know not that, but they hardly left a knight, man, woman, and child were made right honourable.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Right honourable, right worshipful, and well beloved, I have heard that in the country.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: But the fashion of well-beloved is left off, for we do not now love one another.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: But had you no misfortunes?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Faith sir, a rainy day was the worst, and that had but made the ground more soluble the next day for hunting.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: No complaints James?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p:
O yes sir! I hard a gentleman complain mightily that he had lost the highest flying tassel gentle, that ever was seen, another that he had
pricked his grey nag, that was an excellent buckhunter; a third, that he had fretished his best hound, beauty, and that Lilly was killed at a bay a stag-hunting, it had almost cost the gentleman his life.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: And what else James?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: By my troth sir, a gentleman waiter, that shall be nameless, removing a pasty of venison, spilt it all, on a new satin doublet, and spoilt it utterly, there was such laughing, but his master being gracious gave him a suit for his doublet, I think it was a knight; but the knight market is risen now.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I and the lord market too, James.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: And please your worship, they say, the herald would not make a gentleman now, under ten pound.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: O yes, they'll take reason to my knowledge, and give the prettiest fantastical arms, I have all the colours of the rainbow in my new coat, every fool may be a gentleman of three generations now.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: I can derive myself knave three descents under your ancestors.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Then thy children may write themselves knaves of blood, take that upon my heraldry; but had not you brave songs then James?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p:
In those days was the quintessence of ballads, you went to school with 'em, I remember and learned no other books, I shall never forget the lord of Lorne's son in Scotland and the false steward, to the tune of green sleeves, those were the days indeed, o there was then such a company for dancing singing and fooling, I do
not mean the wits, for fooling is another thing clear from it; it does so bravely in company, when there is a great many that care not for wit, and pleases better than all the wit in the world; and then there was such brave jests, at the death of a stag, and buck; to throw blood up and down, upon folks faces; the very footman and pages understood those jests then; there was a time; and the launderers were as well employed in a progress then as now, and the surgeons got as much by 'em too; o, I shall never forget those times.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: So, so, how do I look in this transformation? will anybody know me dost think? Mistress Lucy, shall have the first sight of my shape; somebody is gone into the dining room, let us out at the back door James. Exeunt.

div.stage: (Enter nice. (Dressing the mother, painted) (At another door) Mrs. voluble.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: 'Tis well done nice to be careful about your mistress.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: I am giving her some instructions about dressing, and was saying, she must not go above once to court in black, it would be very scandalous without intermixing colours, in her petticoat, sleeves, and stomacher, and the colours now in fashion are blue, pink, and incarnadine, yellow is much worn too.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: But 'tis very material, what lace you will choose, as silver and gold for blue, (That's a court maxim) and plain silver for incarnadine, single or mixed will serve for pink colour.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: I shall never remember all this.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: It is your gentlewoman's duty to remember.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Let me alone madam. When you will keep house, a long handkerchief, or a round one with a coif tied under your chin, and a little hair curled, with a black taffata hood, or white sarsenet.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: When you pretend to have a cold, you must show no hair, but wear a forehead cloth, with a pinner over that, these clothes are much worn by old ladies, with which they bind down a piece of sercloth upon their forehead, to keep wrinkles in obedience. How is her hair?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: That little that she has is crazy.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: She has enough to curl, and you have the discretion to know what proportion is to be left out, according to the latitude of her face; and to be curled with pins and orrice powder, which will neither hurt nor break it, and then in the morning to let the comb pass through it once, and open it, between a curl and a freeze, and draw up some of the curls with a bodkin within the other hair.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: My hair will never endure all this.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: You must endure more, if you mean to be a lady of fashion, and attractive; where be the pendants?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Must she not wear a feather?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Not without a diamond bodkin; have you no jewels?

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Yes, in the knot of my handkerchief.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: O fie, you must buy a cabinet. What's here? A toad stone, two turkeys, six thumbrings, three aldermen's seals, five gemmals, and four deaths-heads; these are alehouse ornaments — yet these diamonds are tolerable, and these pearls will make a half chain.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Would she were hanged in the fellow, condition we had the rest.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: They must be changed, but nice may wear these till you get new, they will serve to practice in. (Knock within.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: There's a coach at door.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: I'll pawn my ability the French lord, 'tis about the time I gave directions to his footman; for his entertainment, you must take upon you the rich widow, and be you careful to observe Mrs Nices language, garb, and behaviour, to men of his quality; your rings and jewels upon her will credit the cause, and person he comes to visit, which is yourself, but under a veil. I'll prepare his lordship. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: This is all for your instruction; these rings fit me excellent well, and hereafter you may take pride upon you by my example.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: I hope I shall learn in time; but I shall be more than a lady if I marry with a lord.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Alas, I am but the lady in the play.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Now you put me in mind, I have seen pretty harlotry ladies in a country play, so proud, and so knavish, one would have sworn they had been women indeed.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p:
He's here, you must be modest, and observe your distance now; is this the lord? He
looks like an overgrown monkey.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: What pretty foolish things some of these young lords are?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Your lordship is bountiful; that is she whom fame hath delivered to you; your honour may advance.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar dis rish widow look young as myself.

sp.speaker: Vol
sp.p: If my eyes be not in a mist this is the French dancer.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Vat is your name?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: He means to catechise her.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: I shall be happy if your lordship please to own me by the title of your servant.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: You must learn to compliment thus — 'tis galliard sure.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: She kiss very vel begar, she have de alamode touch of de lip ma foy; can you dance madam?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: I am now confirmed.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Will he kiss me too?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Vat is she?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: A gentlewoman that attends me for the present.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Dat is a de reverence for de devil, she look like a de wihch madam, but me tell you madam, for me love you very much in the little time, as any man in de varle; me be French lor, and me have lodging in de autre street, Duke de Memorency my kinsman, and two tre hundred great lors have lose deir head in France begar for no matre, and me fly to England to save a me neck by me trot.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Were you guilty of any treason?

sp.speaker: Gal
sp.p: No more begar than your little self.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: What is your estate?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar very grand estate in Orleans, me have two tre letter from de Cardinal, and he write a me, dat de King send for me to kiss his hand: now as me vas in de resolution to take a de ship for France, me hear of you madam in de strand, and me very glad to marry you before me go presently.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Your lordship is very brief, but I find not myself inclined to cross the seas.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: The sea, marry shield, I'll not see the salt water for any lord in Christendom, ay, I'll rather be no lady.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Who, how now insolence, how dare you interpose?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Will you be ridiculous, and betray yourself now?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar you have de Gipsy complexion, and look like de sign of-de Robin hood and maid a Marian.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Robin hood in thy face, does he maid a Marian me?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: She is not worth your lordship's passion, I shall teach you better manners.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar you shall have much need of dat.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: My lord, you did ask me if I could dance.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: The wench has found him.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Dear is noting in de varle for de lady, like a de understanding in de foot.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: I cannot praise my own ability, but I admire the excellency of other ladies, and should be fortunate to meet with some master in the faculty, that would instruct, and exercise me in private.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Me love you de better for dat, begar nobody exercise you in private but myself, me teach you alamode de court dance, hold up your little finger you command a my foot.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Your lordship is too humble, it is an office would become one that is mercenary; I affect dancing infinitely, o that we had but some music here; la, la, ra. (She sings, Gal. draws out his fiddle.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: 'Tis coming out.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: What's that a bedstaff?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: It is a French pocket-pistol.

sp.speaker: Mother
