sp.p: Will he shoot it oft here? I could never endure a gun. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gal
sp.p: Forboon, brave, ah, dat is like a de Princess, allez.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: You shall not be so public in your graces to me; conceal your fiddle till some private opportunity.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Me understand.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: How does your lordship like her? You have her in an excellent humour.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Kiss a me madam — hah? 'tis heaven? de poet talk of de nectar, begar here is it; me never drink de blank or de claret, so me have but two tre drop divine from your lip — metresse speak a for me.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: The fool is ecstasied; in his worst condition he will serve for a husband; how he dances in a net?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: He has money, and a trade, he will serve wench.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: If me get dis rish widow, me cozen 'em both begar.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Do you think he loves me indeed. Ex. vol.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: You no tinke madam dat me be so hot in love, and do burn, dat my reine a do melt, as me vere in de oven, me need a go into de river presently to cool and vater my heart, vere is de mistress de la maison? Gone? dat is vel, dear is no honour like a dat, as you take a de little air in my coach.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: I have not been abroad today, but I dare trust myself with your lordship.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: O madam, a vostre service, now if me get a de priest all is perfect.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Be all these trunks hers?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: We ha' not stowage enough for half, she is infinitely rich.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Hast thou prepared her?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: I find her very apt, 'tis her only ambition to be a lady, a French lord has her in chase, but I have delivered your character, and what privilege she may have by charter of her knight.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I long to see her, is she handsome?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: What she wants in beauty and breeding, she has in estate sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: That, that's enough, I can have beauty in other places, and will exceed what I conditioned for, if I prosper. I will have this widow in spite.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: How sir William?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: To spite the lady Beaufield, and her Magog that affronted me; I would lose no opportunity, a widow must be taken in the pick; say I am come and commend me to the heavens, I'll make all good.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: To the heavens? will you die before her?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: For that we must take our chance; thou shalt be sure of a good lease for thy life, and destiny agree upon us afterwards.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Shall I direct you?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Shalt be my evening, and my morning star. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: You too much afflict yourself mistress Lucy, 'tis but some humour he put on to try the strength of your affection.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: He is lost; not for my sake, but for his own I pity him, and I am confident, if I were so happy to speak with him again, I should prevail to win him to his first and noble temper; my end being so just, I could dispense with modesty to find him out, and perfect the act of charity.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: You have employed Formall, from whom you may expect to hear such an account, as may dry up your sorrows.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I see sir you preserve your confidence.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I dare be just in your commands, and in a service you but smile upon, despise the censure of the world.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Saw you not the knight since?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: The sweet hopes that he swallowed, to prepare me a ridiculous object to you madam, was gall upon his stomach, when he found you had mercy on my confidence; he dares not converse with so unlicked a bear, as this shape must presentEnter Simpleton, and James.his critical eye sight. What's here? one sent to affront me?

sp.speaker: Simp.

lg.l: When Robin came to Nottingham dery, dery down,
His dinner all for to dine:
There met him fifteen jolly foresters,
Were drinking ale, and wine, hey down.

sp.p: Madam your most humble servant; there be other men, and manners, and garbs as fashionable in the eyes of discreet ladies.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Have we got Adam Bell, and Clim o'th Clough?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: We be three, good Mr. William of Cloudesly.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: 'Tis so.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: And how, and how show matters mistress Lucy? every man's cap is not made of the same matter.
sp.l: Have you felt the wool of beaver?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: — Or sheeps down ever?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: — Have you smelled of the bud of the rose?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: — In his pudding hose.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: — Or have tasted the bag of the bee?
O so fine!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: — O so fond!

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: — O so brave!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: — Such a knave!

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: — Such a knave is he.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Sir, this is most uncivil, and your rashness, beside the forfeit of your own discretion, will lay an imputation to wound my fame; within my presence, and beneath my roof, which should protect all strangers, to affront a gentleman that visits me —

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Be bold sir, and presume you have my favour, you never appeared handsome till this minute; bear up, your mirth becomes you rarely.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Dost i'faith?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: What does my mother mean?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Spit of thy hand, and clap me oth' shoulder James, the widow herself is in love with me.

lg.l: She cast an eye on little Musgrave
As bright as the summer's sun.

sp.p: I may turn o'er the daughter to thee.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: I would I had her in an embroidered clout.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Sure my lady is but in jest.

lg.l: Show me said he whose men ye be
That hunt so boldly here,
That without my consent do chase
And kill my fallow deer. —

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: His fallow deer?

lg.l: Ere thus I will out braved be
One of us two shall die,
I know thee well an Earl thou art,
Lord Percy, so am I.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Thou Douglas?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
This lady has but fooled me all this while; make much of your new antic madam, I can shift into myself again, and if that thing were worth my anger, or my envy, beat him;
you have a pretty humour, cherish it, and that William of the wisp, till I visit you again. —Exit

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: The gentleman is jealous.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I protest madam if it had hot been not your sake, and that it had been pity to have spilt any blood, in your dining room, I would ha' done something

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: In his breeches.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: But I shall report your nobleness abroad.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Do not play the fool to much, I am out of the humour to laugh at you; he cannot leave me thus. —Exit Beau.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: This was no trick to catch the old one.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: How came you into this habit Simpleton?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: By reading Ovid's metamorphosis, and to show the variety of my wit.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Let me entreat you hold your feet together, — now you put me mind of a smith's bellows, your body is not all of a piece sure, but several limbs thrust into several pudding bags, you would show terrible to the crows in a wheat field, you are no living creature.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Persuade me to that, am I not sensible?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: He that does that cure upon you, will deserve a chronicle; so desiring you would take home your flail there, for here is like to be no thrashing work, I commit you to the barn, where like another Orpheus, you will draw the horse, and sheep, to the melody of your voice, and ravish all the cows in the country, to hear you sing Packington's pound. —Exit.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: She has made a coxcomb on you.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p:
Hum? I won't out o'the pit for all this, I
have another device, and thou shalt assist me, if that fail, I'll die a bachelor, and make thee my heir.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: I shall but pray for your death sir.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.l: Back again, back again quoth the pindar,
The wrong way have you gone, etc.

div.stage: A table, stools, bottles of wine, and glasses, set out by two drawers. — then enter Newman, the two jeerers, wenches, musicians.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: So, so, I'll dance no more, a song, let's have a song now.

sp.speaker: 1 wench
sp.p: Take heed of the old ballads, eccliped, like hermit poor, eyes hide my love, or Danae in the brazen tower.

sp.speaker: 2 wench
sp.p: Or the lamentable complaint of Ariadne, and Theseus, and the more lamentable for being so long.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Do you hear madam virtue, lady modesty cannot you play your part?

sp.speaker: 1 je.
sp.p: Not upon the violin.

sp.speaker: 2 Je.
sp.p: They are both for the gamba.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: You shall play the part of my mistress, you must be witty then, and extreme coy and scurvy, in your answers; go behind that hanging, I will suppose it your chamber; now boy the song I made to the window, while I mustle myself with the fiddlers, to bid my mistress good morrow in the street, observe the conjuration.

lg.l: I conjure thee, I conjure thee, by thy skin that is so fair,
thy dainty curled hair,
And thy favour and thy grace,
With the patches on thy face,
And thy hand that doth invite
The cold, dullest appetite,
— appear appear,
Upon these terms I do invite thee,
And if thou comest I will delight thee.
If not so, I do not care,
Though thy breasts be never so bare,
Roses rich, with shoe that's white,
Or thy Venus best delight,
If not touch thy softer skin
What care I for thee a pin,
Appear appear.
For to hear, and not to see
Is a dull flat history,
And to see and not to touch
If you think the last too much,
Know all woman's but one joy
If we men not them enjoy,
Appear appear.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: She's not awake, play a rattling tune that may startle her; where's this whore? ha! —

sp.speaker: 1 Jer.
sp.p: She's gone.

sp.speaker: 2 Jer.
sp.p: Vanished? so he might have sung away his lungs.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: It may be, she is retired, for you know what lady; come let us drink.

sp.speaker: 2 wench.
sp.p:
Was your muse at all this expense
to the fiddles? do you write to no other company sir?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Till they have my liveries; I'll maintain 'em in songs, wind up your voice again ▪

lg.l: Thine eyes to me like suns appear
Or brighter stars their light;
Which makes it summer all the year,
Or else a day of night:
But truly I do think they are
But eyes, and neither sun nor star.
Thy brow is as the milky way,
Whereon the gods might trace:
Thy lips ambrosia I dare say
Or nectar of thy face:
But to speak truly I do vow
They are but women's lips and brow.
Thy check it is a mingled bath
Of lillies and of roses;
But here there's no man power hath
To gather love's fresh posies:
Believe it here the flowers that bud
Are but a woman's flesh and blood.
Thy nose a promontory fair,
Thy neck a neck of land;
At nature's gifts that are so rare
All men amazed do stand:
But to the clearer judgement those
Are but a woman's neck and nose.
For four lines in passion I can die
As is the lover's guise,
and dabble too in poetry
Whilst love possessed, then wise
As greatest statesmen, or as those
That know love best, yet live in prose.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: The pure spirit of sack in't.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: The wit's elixir.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: No jeering gentlemen, I shall grow loud and break the peace.

sp.speaker: 2 wench
sp.p: These gentlemen are for nothing but song and drink, I see no market all this while; I'll get me hence too; if please you, I'll see if I can find out my sister. Ex. 2 Jeer.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: There's but one stool in the counting house, and lady you shall stay till she return; gentlemen there's no life in you; I cannot do this roaring and whoring handsomely; little thinks Lucy what comrades I have got.

sp.speaker: 2 wench
sp.p: I have a precious confidence in you gentlemen, to trust my single modesty amongst so many.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What would you give to be ravished now? thou hast an excellent complexion for't.

sp.speaker: 2 wench
sp.p: Ravished? preserve the gentleman's dear wits sack I beseech thee.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: You would not lose by it if he ravish you.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Another song, and direct your voice to this lady.

lg.l: I'd have her merry, laugh, and smiles
And then look grave and sad:
In every humour but a while,
Make love as 'tis, that's made
I'd have your dress of sever all shapes,
Like Proteus carved, not he,
In humour a she coy jackanapes
Then a grave monkey be.
Discourse of all that comes to sense,
But speak none, yet still speak,
No matter here is no offence,
But to speak matter weak.
With thy soft voice sing me asleep,
Then startle me awake,
With love's notes-passion make me weep,
Then merry for thy sake.

sp.speaker: Jeer. mi
sp.p: A discovery?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What new-found land?

sp.speaker: Jeer. mi
sp.p: The pigeon that left us hath been in another room with Mr. formal my lady Beaufield's gentleman usher, there he sits like the picture of a Harry sovereign in a chair, while she is picking on's pocket.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Fetch him, and his fairy hither, but for his Mrs.'s sake usher him with loud music. Ex. jeer.
We'll have some sport. (Flourish.

div.stage: Enter the two jeerers, and formall.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Where's the wench?

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: The wench has made an escape, she had a glimpse before and suspected me, but here's the wicked elder.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What says my wise Lucullus?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Sir, my business was to you, though I met a remora that is already sunk, I was sent by a gentlewoman, but nobody must know it.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: We hear no business till he have wound up a bottle, and then he shall have audience.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: That's but your fee for entrance, your garnish only; come sir there's no remedy.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: I hope you will conceal it gentlemen.

lg.l: Why then let us drink,
Away scurvy think,
And do't till we wink;
Which is just to be
So drunk not to see.
First Maudlin to weep,
Then after to sleep;
Why they let us drink,
And do't till we wink,
Away scurvy 'Think.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: What will become of me? would you and I lady were in a back room.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: So now speak my lord ambassador, I know your sovereign lady greets us well.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Alas sir, my lady does not know of my coming; I would speak with you from one that shall be nameless, who thinks you are a debauched gentleman, under the rose, and desires to talk with you when you are sober: I would be loath to disgrace you before this good company, neither was I willing to tell her what I heard about your drinking and whoring.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: To the point.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: Ay, ay, to the point.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: The principal matter then, and indeed my whole employment at this time to you is —

sp.speaker: New
sp.p: What in the name of circumspection?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: You shall excuse me sir, silence is a virtue; but if you knew who sent me —

sp.speaker: Wench
sp.p: He would make a costive statesman.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: It is sufficient one desires to speak with you, I name no time, nor person, I know my office; mistress Lucy is not to be named at all times.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Mistress Lucy, I am her servant; come drink this narrow sea to her health, you must be drunk infallibly, I'll give a reason; I swear by muscadel that I do love her well; come ye mermaids —

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: I'll do you reason then; but is this muscadel? Mr. Newman has sworn; for my own part, gentlemen, I desire it should go no further.

lg.l: I swear by muscadel
That I do love thee well,
And more than I can tell.
By the white, claret, and sack
I do love thy black, black, black,
I do love thy black, black, black.
No goddess 'mongst them all
So slender, and so tall,
And grateful too with all,
Which makes my sinews to crack
For thy black, black, black,
For thy dainty black, black.
So lovely, and so fair,
Though shadowed with thy hair,
So nimble, just like air;
All these set me on love's wrack
For thy black, black, black,
For thy dainty black, black.
Thy kind and cunning eye,
When first it did espy,
Our love it did descry,
Dumbe speaking, what d'ye lack?
Mine answered, thy black, black,
Thy dainty black, black, black.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: Excellent!

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Now give Mr. formal his cup.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: I have had the narrow sea, I cannot drink an ocean.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: His tother cup; you had my wench as I remember, and I'll prescribe you a penance; there's another whore for you, drink to her and she shall pledge.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Give me thy hand, and set thy foot to mine.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: You may trust your single modesty with him.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: For my own part, I had rather do things privately; come kiss me first — here's to thee, my flesh tingles —

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: A word with you two squires.

sp.speaker: Wench
sp.p: Any thing for a shelter, I foresee a storm; and what is one cat among so many mastiffs?

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: You are melancholy.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: You lie, you that say nothing lie, if you be of his opinion.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: methinks we are very merry.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: We are exceeding merry.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Have you discharged your culverin? where's the paraquito?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: I drunk it off.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: She is vanished too.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p:
Then we are ourselves, and make me
your example; you know your province sirrah, make ready for an angel, sing the design of honour, and of fancy. Ex. boy.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: But first in fancy we will fool,
Pull off our doublets, drink more cool,
Our hats upon our heads not stay,
For each health we'll throw them away
So periwig, or fringe, or border,
The naked truth we'll drink in order.
And to the music as they play
A fancy piece we'll throw away,
Until we are drained, can draw no more,
And the next day all cry therefore.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Off with Formall's doublet, off with his doublet, throw't into the fire, that's a good fancy; now he is formal right.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: I did not drink hard, for I am cold, the wench would keep me warm, she's a notable fire-drake; will it please you sir to go to the party?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Now does he betray what a bawd he would be.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Does nobody know where to get a serpent with two legs that hath never a sting?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I have a great mind to drink a health in one of my boots.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: I drink no beer glasses, if a shoe will serve turn —

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: His shoe, my scabbard, a match.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: My glove.

sp.speaker: 2 jeer
sp.p: His cap.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Fill brimmers, every man to his mistress; now do not I like this fancy.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: We ha' don't.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: There's wool in my scabbard, which is a spongious matter, and when I ha' done(Music throne descendsI may leave my drink behind me, and that's a hanging matter, which I am principally to avoid — do you hear the music of the spheres gentlemen?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: 1 jeer
sp.p: From the roof a throne?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: This room is mine, and called the field of Tempe; because I won't stay while(The wench peeps from under the table.the plays are done when I have a humour to be merry, and drink healths in the clouds, I built this Elysium; and when bright sack hath crowned my brow, how soon I am made immortal, you may guess.

lg.head: A song in the throne.
lg.l: As I singing now came down,
I do bring you Bacchus crown:
From the plump lord of the vine
Clustered grapes to make you wine,
Your swelled temples circling in,
Crowned with this, and bathed within;
Therefore your best wishes bring,
Place this garland on your King.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Is not Bacchus the best good fellow God on 'em all? Let me see, formal shall be King, and he sent to heaven presently.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Send me to heaven? why should I be sent thither before another man?

sp.speaker: 2 jeer
sp.p: Ret, ret, verily ret, here's the partridge under the table.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: They'll be good company, they shall both be immortal together, help gentlemen. Boy you must be deposed.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Alas what shall I do?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: You shall to heaven lady?

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: What before my time? and whether I will or no?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: It shall be with as much ease, as if it were in a featherbed.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Let us sleep together.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Ah pity a poor gentlewoman, if you have hearts of flesh, do not use me worse than heathen prentices.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: So crown 'em, and give to each a glass of wine, for a sceptre.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Gentlewoman, if we must mount, 'tis none of our seeking, we are but angels in our own defence, for my own part, I desire to go thither in no better company.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Up with 'em, and preserve your sceptre glasses, do not spill your blood royal.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Alas, hold there for heaven's sake, I must meet three inns of court gentlemen at the stillyard tonight , it may be out of my way 20. pound, consider your own cases.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Peace gentle Queen of grapes.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Thou art a traitor too, o!

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Do not jog the chariot, let us take our preferment patiently, and drink a health to the humble mortals, that turn up their whites to us, this is pretty high drinking.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Drunkards, devils? o that I were upon earth again. —

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: Is this the gentlewoman's wine, or water?

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: He mounts insensibly.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: They have a heavenly time on't; you know me sirrah.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Noble Mr. Newman.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: There's for your attendance.

sp.speaker: Jeer.
sp.p: What's to pay?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: They shall pay you the reckoning in the other world, you know the back way thither; come my boys to the departed, having paid all rites
We now return.

sp.speaker: Jeerers.
sp.p: Like woeful Adamites.

div.head: Act. v. Scaena. i.
div.stage: Enter Simpleton, James, (Little table set out.)

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I am resolved, since fair means cannot prevail with mistress Lucy, to steal her away, this is the key of the back-gate o'th' garden, to the fields, be ready when I give the sign to hurry her into the coach, and when I have her at my countryhouse, I'll take in her maiden town, upon my own composition.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: You won't ravish her.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: There are twenty ways to deal with a woman, and never ravish her; no, I have played the fool too much.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: I am of your opinion.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: But she shall find if I get possession. —

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: The coachman is a lusty fellow too, and will help to clap her abroad; the curtains being close she cannot be heard, and the horses will run, as the devil were in the poop, for he drives like a Tamberlaine.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Holla ye pampered jades.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: One traitor more were not amiss for all that.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Thou sayest right, for though she be a little woman, her voice may be too strong for us.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Let us alone, mind your own part.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Be resolute James. — Exit Simp.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: The course I am in, hath brought some men to the gallows, and do I take it for prevention?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: What desperate fellow's that?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I am weary of wine and noise, is there no other cure for melancholy? I do not love the cramp in my neck.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: He looks like a gentleman that were in debt; my friend do you come hither to find a tree? thou'rt a proper fellow, dost want employment, for though your clothes have a good gloss, they look as they were ill lined, they want money.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I suffer that which made the old woman mend her pace fir.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Do as I'll direct thee.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Whom do you serve?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: I serve myself; my master is a fool; did you never hear of Simpleton?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: That worshipful puppy?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: He knows him. I have seen you before, but 'tis no matter where; I like thy countenance; canst keep counsel? walk o'this hand o'me.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Nay a little further mistress Lucy, it seems Mrs voluble told him no great good fortune, she saw it in his stars, for you know she wears astrology at her apron strings; but she told me in private who should be the man, your dear Endymion.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Who I beseech you?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: The object is presented, and 'tis in vain to oppose the constellations, what must be must be, and there were no more ladies in the world, I am the man.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: To steal her away?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: My master is resolved. They are here; close.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: She is betrayed. —

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Now. —

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Help; thieves.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Stop her mouth.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Then every man take his chance.

div.stage: (He strikes down Simpleton. Lucy runs off.)

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Murder, murder.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Are you so cunning sir? you shall along with us. (They disarm New.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Worried by hedgehogs!

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Are you not killed outright sir?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I am not certain, be sure you hold him fast; to the next justice; I must get a surgeon. You are my rival, I know you well enough, if I miscarry, it shall cost me a hundred pound, but I'll ha' thee hanged for't. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: I understand you perfectly mistress voluble, and like your proposition; but a word more of the widow that is at your 'House, she is very rich you say?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Not in understanding.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: 'Tis the better.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Here's all your worship must promise her, to be knighted, for she hath a great mind to be a lady.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: I know where a blank lies dormant for a baronet, it will carry more noise and authority on the bench too.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: You have done me some discourtesy here tofore, in believing the complaints of intemperate tongues against me, but you see my charity I desire to live in your worship's fair opinion as a neighbour.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: I will make you amends sweet mistress valuable, you're a virtuous gentlewoman on my conscience: but how shall this widow be wrought?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p:
That's done already. The truth is she enquired
of me, (For we women use to open our secrets one to another) for some staid gentleman that was a lawyer, (Because she has so great an estate, and many suits to follow) on whom she might bestow herself, for the security of her fortune, and I have already prepared her, and such a commendation of your person, and learned gravity, a justice of peace and quorum, out of my private respects to you, without desire or expectation of any bribe or reward.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: I understand that very well.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: I know you do.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: How much I am bound to your virtue?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: The widow has a great mind to see you, but I will contrive it for your honour, she shall come hither, as to her learned counsel.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: The invincible wit of a woman! how I honour it.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: There can be no loss in't if you get a chaplain in readiness, widows are taken in the opportunity.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: A gentleman brought to be examined, that has wounded one master Simpleton.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Simpleton? that's the widow's son.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Richard, send to the curate of the parish, say I would speak with him presently.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Alas who hurt you?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: My rival master Newman, is this the justice?

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p:
A former quarrel; if you die, I have seen
enough to make it murder, for your good mother's sake.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Cannot you make it manslaughter, and let me live? for I desire but his death.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: He shall make it what you please. This gentleman is to be knighted, and loves your mother above all the world, things meet as close, as if they went to engender.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: My mother is worth six thousand pound, if you will promise to make her a lady, and do your best to hang the gentleman, you shall be my father in law, when my landlady says the word.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Sir I'll take my leave.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Sweet mistress voluble, leave your friend to me, I understand the matter perfectly, and it shall go hard, but we will have all the law on our side. Call in the offender; please you sit; Richard be ready with your ammunition, pen, ink and paper.

div.stage: Enter surgeon, Newman, James, coachman, constable and officers.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: What is your name sir?

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.p: My name is Seare.

sp.speaker: Clerk
sp.p: He is the surgeon sir.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: I'll teach you to follow your profession sirrah, I'll make you an example to all phlebotomers; how often have you been indicted for letting of blood sirrah?

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.p: I understand you nor.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p:
But I understand you sirrah; how durst you vi et armis, feloniously assault this noble gentleman in contempt of piece, and the King's law,
his crown and dignity? answer me sirrah to that. I'll seize him.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.p: You worship is mistaken, I never see the gentleman before, I was sent for —

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: He is the surgeon sir, that is come to take measure of my master's wounds, it was that gentleman that let him blood.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Why do they not change faces then? away you knave, and look to the gentleman; you stand idling here to stumble authority with a felonious countenance.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Let us be for sworn both in a tale.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Sir, you are one that should do justice; where is my poor friend? be not so much dejected, you did but rescue me sir from dishonour.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I was in a melancholy humour; 'tis come about as the wise woman concluded.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Where's Simpleton? I may accuse him for a rape.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Take heed what you say.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Or some such black intent; this gentleman but interposed to save me from their fury, and with his sword punished a bold offender by letting out some blood that was corrupted.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: That's not material; will you confess you wounded master Simpleton? come to the matter.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I confess it sir, but hear the reason.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p:
I will hear no reason, that were simple justice; take him aside, and you may follow your
business. Stay young gentlewoman, I must examine you.

sp.speaker: Clerk
sp.p: Shall I withdraw, and shut the door?

div.stage: Exeunt all but justice and Lucy.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What justice sir, or law is this?

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: It is not Polton, Crompton, nor Fitzerhert, a justice ought to have some discretion without book, especially in these cases. I grant you are the root and cause of this misfortune.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I sir?

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Be wise, and understand me; and being endued with such gifts of nature, native beauty and favour, (Come a little nearer) and you to abuse yourself —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How sir?

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Or suffer yourself to be abused (Come a little nearer) is not to be thankful for those excellent benefits.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Will you translate an insolence in others upon my guilt?

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: You accuse an honest gentleman for an intent of rape; alas poor soul, it was pure affection in him, he would have ravished you no doubt, with your own consent, the fault was your ingratitude, (A little nearer) Seneca doth write much of ingratitude, that I may come (A little nearer) or else Nero had not let him blood, (Yet nearer) this Nero was a most wicked tyrant, for all he could play upon a fiddle, make ballads, and sing them himself, and therefore take heed of cruelty, and be gentle,He kisseth her.for, sweetheart Nero died a violent death.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: My mother.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Lucy you made haste.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Your pardon madam.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: I understand she is a lady.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: In the defence of my own virtue, and the noble gentleman that suffers for his charity to me —

sp.speaker: Beauf.
sp.p: I came to assist you. It were an injury to doubt your justice. My name is Beaufield. If my credit may be interposed security for Newman my daughter's knowledge in the cause willEnter clerk.give a most clear satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Richard, call in the delinquent, this lady has spoken very much to the matter, as I understand it. Has the surgeon done yet?

sp.speaker: Clerk
sp.p: They are coming down.

div.stage: Enter surgeon, Newman, Simpleton, James, constable, officers.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Now sir, how many of his wounds are mortal?

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.p: There is not one considerable, the gentleman is in no danger.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: But have not you authority to hang him? I'll take my oath, he had an intent to kill me. My lady and mistress Lucy? James, I'll stay no longer, since I am not mortally wounded, sneak after me.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: My hanging fit is over, and the witchcraft, I am now myself again, if you can pardonEnter Manley.me madam this too great an honour to your worthless servant.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: How now? what saucy fellow's this?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: She's here too. I am bold cousin to visit you, they say, there's a gentleman brought before you, for breach o'th' peace, I come to bail him.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: We take no foreigners; what outlandish thing are you, pray?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: You know me sir, my name is Manley, you called me cozen yesterday.

sp.speaker: Lust
sp.p: I never saw you before. I know that name, and a gentleman that owns it, a kinsman of mine too, but he is no such Brandemart. Richard, do you know this Mahound? he calls himself my cousin manly.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Why in this habit?

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Transmigration?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Is it not some spy sir?

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Constable take him to your charge. I'll teach you sirrah, to usurp a gentleman's name; 'tis felony ipso facto, write his mittimus.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: By what statute? Trigesimo secundo of King Philip? I do not madam desire your certificate.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: You're a stranger sir to me, yet I dare be engaged for his forth coming, he has an honest face.

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: Come hither Richard, there's half a piece, rub thy eyes wilt, are they open yet?

sp.speaker: Clerk
sp.p:
I see you plainly now sir, you're my masters
cozen, 'tis master Manley.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: 'Tis your best course to own me too; is it so long since you took bribes, since you divided and manumised a crooked chambermaid that robbed her mistress of old gold? there was a lancepresado stripped a hedge, when you were out of linen; pewter has been left at the backdoor, when you did study alchemy; I leave the trick you showed the sailor's wife in your closet, when you promised a reprieve to her goodman from Wapping; I know not that you have run your withered motley face into a praemunire; do not know me, why d'ye not charge the constable?

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: What is a justice without eyes, I mean spectacles? 'tis he indeed, I understand, and see him perfectly; welcome, a chair for my cousin?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: So then. Madam a word with you, I'll make you know me too, ere I ha' done.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: There is a matted chamber and a couch — more business?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Vere is de matre justice? begar day have put de shear upon me, me expect de rish vidow, and have marry the chambermaid, she confess dat, maitre justice, pray take her to yourself, me desire your warrant, for metresse voluble, dat she bring the vidow Simpleton to marry me sans ceremony, dat is your commission, or begar me complain of you to de King.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Did you expect the rich widow Simpleton? ha, ha! I know this trifle, my clerk knows her better

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Bergar matre justice, and matre clerk make your division, dat is all you see.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Sir I have only cause to complain, he told me he was a French lord, mistress voluble shall make affidavit, and courted me to be his lady, and now we are married, he proves but a cinquepace. I looked for thousands per annum, and he is but one, two, three, four, and five.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: How, did he pretend himself to be a lord? 'tis scandalum magnatum in the highest degree: and by a statute quinquagesimo of the Queen, if she prosecute, he is to be whipped, and lose his ears three several market days.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: How will you divide his ears into three equal portions?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Me give a de whip, and me lose a mine 'Ears!

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: You hear the law, if I complain.

sp.speaker: I. jeer
sp.p: Sir — mistress voluble —

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Is the widow come?

sp.speaker: I jeer
sp.p: The gentlewoman is come, and desires to speak with your worship in private.

sp.speaker: Clerk
sp.p: The curat's in the hall sir.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: So, so, I must entreat your patience for a few minutes; how I am blessed! Exit.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Tell a me de trot, have you no argent, no portion?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: But I have a trade.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I dare be sworn thou hast.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
Awe dat is something, here is my hand, you no tell a de tale, a me, and me keep yourEnter sir William, and mother.
Secret by my trot.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I took boldness madam upon sight of your ladyship's new coach at the door, to intrude and present a poor forsaken servant; give you joy of your old fashioned young gentleman.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Your companion wants no antiquity, if she have no wizard on.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I hope you are not married sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: The matters done, and 'tis more honourable to make a lady than to marry one. Does anybody know this gentlewoman, she was a widow till this morning, and a rich one I thank my stairs, and wants the subtle art, some ladies have to make themselves ridiculous, by doting upon antics.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: What name has your most reverend lady?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: She was called the wealthy widow of old Simpleton, before I married her.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: What is't makes you so merry monsieur?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar somebody make arrant ass of de knight, hold a me, or me shall crack a my rib wi' de laugh, dat is no simpleton, but an autre chambermaid, de servant to my vife, begar he be sheated too.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: I must confess she waited upon me.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Ma foy dat is certain, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: I defy her, that was but a plot.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
Begar it was very fine a plot, me have
patience, dat dear be more fool in de comedy.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Mistress voluble can justify what I am, that I am, or would I might ne'er be, a lady, and I be'nt, that I be'nt.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I will have justice.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: You may have him sir.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: The reason of this noise my right worshipful?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Give me a warrant presently.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Against whom?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Voluble, I'll have her whipped.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Wrong not the virtuous gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Virtuous? vexation.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Why do you take on so, of my conscience she is honest enough; does this woman look like a whore?

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: I thank you gentleman.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: She has gravity enough to be a bawd, and then the worst is past.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Is not the widow weight, not perfect sterling?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: This is not the widow.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: What widow?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: The rich widow Simpleton.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: I do believe it, did she promise you marriage?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: The devil's proctor mistress voluble made me believe so.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p:
Do not wrong I say again that virtuous gentlewoman mistress voluble, I know her, and know her virtuous, but the rich widow Simpleton, you talk of (Thanks be to providence) is
newly married, the priest hath scarce wiped his oraculous lips, since they pronounced us, manEnter voluble, and two jeerers (At one door) Simpleton, at the other.)and wife, in my stone parlour, in good faith la, she's here, her own tongue will confirm it gentlemen.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Why does she veil her face.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: It is her modesty, to hide her blushes, that I should so soon prevail upon her: and thus the morning breaks out of the clouds.

sp.speaker: Simpl
sp.p: By your leave landlady, where's my mother.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Mistress voluble?

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Here's my son, he shall be a witness I am his mother, I am married to this knight, and they would persuade me out of myself.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: 'Tis come about again, is this your mother?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I have asked her blessing in my days.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: There is no remedy, 'twas your own curate did it.

sp.speaker: Jeer
sp.p: Give you joy Mr. justice.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Conspiracy, is there no law for this?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Yes, yes, the canon law, and you must keep her.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Let me obtain madam your fair construction, sir William you are sped to your desires, and you are fitted monsieur galliard, but nice, the jewels must return to their right owner.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Excuse a moy.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: It must be so, I keep my wedding ring for thee sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p:
I ask you pardon sir, and mistress Lucy,
I had a plot upon your loves, to endear young Simpleton, in hope your credulous nature, to avoid melancholy, might have been engaged to some licentious rudeness, and so made yourself unworthy of her affection, but here I must confess I have no skill in stars nor fortune telling, and am but one among the rest that have deceived your easy faith, forgive me, as I wish you may thrive in your affections.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I am confirmed.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Nay then let marriages go round, with this take both possession of my heart and fortunes.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: You but enlarge my power to do you service.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Your love, and joys be constant. Mr. justice you must embrace mistress voluble.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Well, I will love thee for thy wit; but no more wandering.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: You wholly sir shall steer me, and to invite more welcome from you sir, I have not lived upon the common charity, I have a state is not to be despised.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Sayest thou so, we'll put our stocks together and live merrily.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Will they not take his word? alas poor formal, there, there's their ransom, bid the whore be honest, I'll plead his reconcilement to my lady.

sp.speaker: Jeer ma.
sp.p: I am gone.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: But d'ye hear, must I ha' no wench, at the end of the play? that have taken all this pains? what will you do with me?

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p:
Well remembered, this lady did accuse
him; though I missed of the mother, I will make sure of the son, make his warrant for Newgate presently.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: How sir?

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: I know how very well sir.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: You called it love before, I freely pardon him.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Let this day be consecrate to peace, and Hymen.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: And the night to Venus; let it be so, and thank this gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I thank you all, and will never trust a witch for your sake, I'll go seek out my wits.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Let no man part, so many hearts here tided,
Stay till we drink a health to every bride.
Flourish —

A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length.
